text: A seedy neighborhood. LARRY "DOC" SHEPHERD, wearing a hea windbreaker, stands idly on the street. An AWOL bag is on sidewalk at his feet. A garment bag is slung over his shoulder. He studies the little working-man's bar across street as the title "DECEMBER 13, 2003" comes up.

Small and dark. A pool table, a few booths, not much deco SAL NEALON leans on his elbows on his side of the bar, do a crossword. He's in his late 50s and wears a cropped mustache, going gray, like the sides of his short-cropped hair. He wears a black T-shirt, revealing a USMC tattoo o his arm. He smokes a cigar, chewing its end more than it needs. An edgy dude - you wouldn't want to fuck with him. the other end of the bar, COPS is on a TV that hangs suspended from the ceiling. On the show, a nervous couple to explain to a sarcastic cop what they are doing in the projects if not buying drugs. Sal's only customer, O'TOOL an old functioning alcoholic, is watching. At some point enters, pausing near the door. O'Toole gives him a cursor glance. Doc hangs his garment bag on a hook on the stanch and takes a stool. He puts his AWOL bag on another stool settles down with a little uncertainty.
I ask you, you ever see these cops catch a killer or a rapist on this show? Ever see them put the cuffs on some crooked CEO fuck? Wanders over to Doc.
What can I get you?
Beer.
What kind?
Doesn't matter.
Bottle or draft?
Draft. (CONTINUED)
Sal walks back over and starts filling up a glass while h continues his conversation with O'Toole.
Nah, they're always just drug users and johns... just people hurtin', trying to find a little pleasure in life.
What have you got against cops?
Nuttin'. What I got something against is good ol' stupidity. Sal wanders back to Doc and serves him the beer. Doc look into a manila envelope and withdraws a five dollar bill a lays it on the bar.
You comin' or goin'?
Passing through, kind of. (about money) Keep it. Sal takes Doc's money, puts it in the register, and goes to his crossword.
Good beer.
Yeah, it's from Pennsylvania.
How long have you had this place?
Too long.
It's real homey.
You think so? Where the hell do you live? Doc doesn't get Sal's wit.
New Hampshire. Portsmouth. (CONTINUED)
Sal is back on his puzzle.
Home of the Navy prison.
I know the place.
It's an okay town. (drinks) So you're Sal.
That I am.
So Sal, how do you suppose I knew that?
Name's on the sign outside. Doc smiles, looks around, turns to O'Toole.
Not exactly a hot spot, huh?
Not anymore.
I like it, though. It's homey.
Yeah, you said that. That's why I was worried about where you lived.
You don't remember me, do you?
I don't remember half the women I fucked, and that's just the ones I didn't have to pay. How am I supposed to remember you?
Well, I remember you. Sal looks at him more closely, squints. The cigar droops. (CONTINUED)
Can't be.
Could be.

Way.
Sweet Jesus... Doc?
(bemused ) Doc... Nobody's called me that ina long, long time.
Fuck me. You made it, Doc.
Yeah.
O'Toole, look at this. Old buddy from 'Nam. I saved his life once.
Then you must be some kind of fuckin' hero.
He never saved my life.
Didn't think so.
And now he's come to kick my ass.
Long overdue and well deserved. I'll hold his coat for him.
No, I'm not here for that.
You gotta excuse me, Doc. I'm shit for names. (CONTINUED)
Shepherd. Larry Shepherd.
Right. Shepherd. Nineteen year-old kid. Navy corpsman.
Once.
Yeah, well, we were all something once. Now we're something else.
So you do remember me?
‘Course I do, you saved my fuckin' life.
I thought it was the other way around.
You heard, I got busted down to E- One?
Most unfair. The green weenie - they broke it off in you. What can I say, dear, after I say I'm sorry?
How's Mueller?
Ol' Mueller the Mauler. Maybe he's alive. How should I know? Have another beer. On the house. Fuck, I'll have one with you.
You're not in touch with him?
Saw him medevacked out, and that's all she wrote.
Mueller got hit? (CONTINUED)
Oh, yeah, you weren't there by then... it was not pretty. Sal now comes over closer to Doc.
I still think I rate credit for a save.
Who? What?
You, you fuck. I saved your life.
I don't remember anything like that.
Captain said, Doc is coming unhinged. He's gonna blow. Take him for two days to Pleiku. Show him around Disneyland.
I do remember Disneyland.
Hell yeah you do.
But all I remember is gettin' laid and drunk.
Well, yeah... that's why it was there.
Mueller was with us.
I did that too. I said, Cap'n, Doc's too fucked up for one person to handle. Take Mueller, he said.
(sarcastic) Oh, yeah, and things were much better after that. (CONTINUED)
C'mon, Doc, we had a good time, didn't we? We had some fun.
Sure we did. Not sayin' we didn't.
We did, the three of us.
Yeah. I laugh sometimes when I think about it.
Really? Do you?
Yeah, kind of.
Why not? You got to laugh at every- fuckin-thing. I laugh at my prostate gland, little son of a bitch, laugh every time the doctor gives me a fingerwave, two times a year.
It's good you know how to do that. Wish I could do that.
So what was it, three years?
Ended up about two, with good behavior.
That's not so bad.
It was pretty bad, but it was a long time ago.
Yeah, but at some point instead of calling it a Bad Conduct Discharge, I started calling it a better career decision. (CONTINUED)
Fuckin-A. You're alive and upright. So you got out, and then what? You stayed there?
Didn't really have anywhere else to go.
Fuck all. Listen here, how did you find my lonesome ass?
Easy. On the internet. You can find anybody on the internet these days.
That's fucked. Doc kind of laughs as O'Toole gives them fresh beers.
So whaddaya do in Portsmouth, for a living?
Stocking clerk, at the Navy Exchange.
You're shitting me.
(old joke between them) I wouldn't shit you, you're my favorite turd. LATER - O'Toole is asleep on the pool table. Doc is crawl into a booth. Sal is also finding a spot to lay down.
(stretching out) Don't you go someplace when you close?
Like where?
I don't know, home?
It'll be there tomorrow.

A dreadful little space full of generational stains and graffiti. Sal washes his face, pulls out some paper towel and dries. He looks at his reflection in the mirror. This the face he has earned. This is the place he has landed.

(sitting up) What's the deal with the grill part of Sal's Bar & Grill?

Used to put out a righteous burger. Serious meat with a nice slice of raw onion and nothin' else, except for mustard and ketchup, of course. No lettuce or pickles or any of that crap. But people lost their taste for honest hamburgers, so I let the grill go. Why? You hungry?

I'm always up for it. Shoot.
You got a car?
I'm a fuckin businessman, of course I got a car. (stirs O'Toole) Yo, O'Toole, open up for me today, okay? O'Toole nods his head, then goes back to sleep.
Not much of a car. A 20-year-old Taurus Wagon. Sal drives through a light drizzle, on a rural road.
I just fuckin' love it, you know? It's like priceless.
What is?
The Navy. They put the cock to you, then they let you work at the Navy fuckin' Exchange.
I got five people under me.
You're a fuckin' inspiration.
You know what amazes me about you? (CONTINUED)
Could be anything. I'm a pretty amazing guy.
You turn over your bar to a customer, you get in your car, and you drive me to hell and gone, and you don't even know where we're going.
I didn't think it would take so fuckin' long. Doc refers to a folded up MapQuest sheet of paper.
A humble building that might have been a barn once. It la a steeple and stained glass, but it makes up for it with spirit we will encounter inside. We see the Taurus Wagon the parking lot.
You gotta be kiddin' me.
Sal looks at the place, doubtfully.
C'mon, you're gonna love this. I promise.
I don't know, Doc, you seen one, you seen them all. Doc grins as they start to get out of the car.

A small black congregation, listening intently to a sermo Sal and Doc enter, drawing some notice, but then space is made for them. A middle-aged preacher is at the pulpit wi the aid of a cane. It is MUELLER.
..--Now remember, Jesus and Judas, they were friends... As the sermon continues, Sal leans toward Doc, whispers: (CONTINUED)
Oh. My. Fucking. God. Is that who I think it is?
I told you you'd like this. Sal is wildly amused. He turns and looks around at the others, wanting to share his excitement.
But, oh, how a good man can be laid low by a false friend, how havoc can follow the lying smile...
Amen!
Amen, brother! (whispers to Doc) The dude was a world-class drinker, gambler and cocksman.
Shhhh.
And likely a speed freak. How the hell did you find this place?
The internet.
Oh, yes, in the spirit of friendship, have a drink... have a toke... have a snort... the devil has a friendly face and a winning way. But behind that smile, as behind the kiss of Judas...

(whispers) I think he's makin' this shit up just for us. Reverend Mueller eventually finishes his sermon, looking closely at his two visitors... a long judgemental look. A echoing of Amens rolls wall to wall.
(shouting out) Oh, Amen, brother! Amen! (CONTINUED)
Thank you, brothers and sisters, and praise the Lord for our fellowship here today.
Praise the Lord!

I see we have some visitors among us today. Welcome to our Sunday services. Would you like to stand and introduce yourselves? Sal needs no second invitation. He springs to his feet, s off a salute and sounds off:

Salvatore Nealon, Sergeant, U.S. Marine Corps, retired. Heads in the congregation turn. Whispers become a buzz th fill the church. The Reverend totters a bit at the pulpit holding on. RUTH, Mueller's concerned wife, studies how h husband is responding. Doc tugs at Sal's sleeve, but Sal pulls him to his feet.
And guess who this lad is.
Mueller, Ruth and their two guests sit at a table laden w a ham and heaping bowls of vegetables and greens. Mueller sits rigidly, his eyes on Sal and Doc, wary.
Man, oh, man, southern ham, thank you, ma'am. Listen here, Ruth, I hope this old man appreciates you.

‘Cause if ever he don't, just pack a bag and come live with Sal.
You don't have a wife? (CONTINUED)
No, ma'am, neither chick nor child. I do have a lady friend, but she don't cook worth a damn. She has other talents, if you know what I mean. Embarrassed, she turns to Doc.

The light of my life, my Mary. A heart as big as... anything. A real pretty girl, with a great big smile...
Nice...

I'm so sorry. Sal stops with fork in mid path.
Sorry, Doc. You know me, I didn't mean nothin’.
We pay for the things we say, Salvatore.

Your tab is long overdue, I suspect.

Richard and I have a boy and a girl, and we have four grandchildren.
Richard?
(quickly) Honey, don't you have some coffee and pie for our visitors, before we send them on their way?
(rising) I have a peach cobbler for dessert. (CONTINUED)

(to Doc) I'm glad to see you prevailing over your hardships.
Doin' my best.

Fuck if I remember. Somebody hit me on the head with something. I believe drink was involved. He laughs. The other two can't manage it. LATER - They sit in the living room having cobbler and 11 coffee. Doc hasn't touched his, Sal digs into his, while practically flirting with Ruth.
